reasoning:
Essay A is substantially better as it provides a complete and well-developed exploration, fulfilling all aspects of Criterion B, whereas Essay B has significant omissions and flaws in its experimental design. Essay A establishes a strong scientific context with a detailed introduction and background, linking the topic of dissolved oxygen to a real-world application ("fish business") and thoroughly explaining the underlying chemistry of the "Winkler Method" with relevant equations. In contrast, Essay B is entirely missing an introduction or background section, failing to establish any context for why calcium content in milk is being investigated.

Furthermore, Essay A's methodology is robust, detailed, and replicable, outlining a clear plan to manipulate the independent variable ("Preparing Different concentrations of Salt in water") and control others ("The experiment was done in a water bath of which was set to keep temperature constant at 10°C"). Essay B's methodology is incomplete; while it details the titration procedure, it critically fails to explain how the independent variable—the expiration date—will be managed over time. Essay A also demonstrates a superior understanding of experimental design by explicitly defining all variables (independent, dependent, controlled) in a table with justifications, a fundamental component that Essay B completely omits. Finally, while both essays include risk assessments, Essay A's is more comprehensive, explicitly addressing "Safety, Environmental and Ethical considerations" in separate, well-reasoned points. Essay B even acknowledges a major flaw in its own chosen method ("EDTA is known to collect other substances apart from calcium such as magnesium"), which reflects a poorly considered experimental design from the outset.

Essay A establishes a strong scientific context with a detailed introduction and background, linking the topic of dissolved oxygen to a real-world application ("fish business") and thoroughly explaining the underlying chemistry of the "Winkler Method" with relevant equations. In contrast, Essay B is entirely missing an introduction or background section, failing to establish any context for why calcium content in milk is being investigated.\n\nFurthermore, Essay A\'s methodology is robust, detailed, and replicable, outlining a clear plan to manipulate the independent variable ("Preparing Different concentrations of Salt in water") and control others ("The experiment was done in a water bath of which was set to keep temperature constant at 10°C"). Essay B\'s methodology is incomplete; while it details the titration procedure, it critically fails to explain how the independent variable—the expiration date—will be managed over time. Essay A also demonstrates a superior understanding of experimental design by explicitly defining all variables (independent, dependent, controlled) in a table with justifications, a fundamental component that Essay B completely omits. Finally, while both essays include risk assessments, Essay A\'s is more comprehensive, explicitly addressing "Safety, Environmental and Ethical considerations" in separate, well-reasoned points. Essay B even acknowledges a major flaw in its own chosen method ("EDTA is known to collect other substances apart from calcium such as magnesium"), which reflects a poorly considered experimental design from the outset.',
    decision='essay_a'
)
